Nano-rod catalysts: Building MOF bottles (MIL-101 family as heterogeneous single-site catalysts) around vanadium oxide ships Razieh Fazaeli a * Hamid Aliyan b Majid Moghadam c Mona Masoudinia a a Department of Chemistry, Shahreza Branch, Islamic Azad University, 86145-311, Iran Department of Chemistry Shahreza Branch, Islamic Azad University 86145-311 Iran b Department of Chemistry, Mobarakeh Branch, Islamic Azad University, 84815-119, Iran Department of Chemistry Mobarakeh Branch, Islamic Azad University 84815-119 Iran c Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University, Isfahan 81746-73441, Iran Department of Chemistry Isfahan University Isfahan 81746-73441 Iran * Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 321 3232706x7; fax: +98 321 3232701. Graphical abstract Porous materials based on chromium (III) terephthalate metal organic frameworks (Cr-MIL(101)) and their new composites with vanadium oxide has emerged as a potential catalyst because of its high specific surface area, tunable pore size, and unique structure. The structural and textural characterization of V@MIL(101) were done using FTIR, X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption–desorption, and TEM. XRD and adsorption–desorption analysis shows that the mesostructure of MIL-101 remains intact after vanadium oxide modifications, while spectral technique show the successful immobilizing of the neat vanadium oxide inside the MIL-101 cavities. These new catalysts were found to be highly effective for selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides and sulfones with H2O2 at room temperature and the 4.2% V@MIL(101) catalyst showed the highest activity. The PW12@MCFim heterogeneous system showed high catalytic oxidative activity in the treatment of commodity gasoline. Keywords Supported vanadia catalyst Impregnation method Single-site catalysts (SSC) MOF bottles (MIL-101(Cr)) 1 Introduction The single-site heterogeneous catalysts (SSHCs) are usually associated with transition-metal-containing molecular sieves or supported catalysts prepared by grafting or anchoring techniques [1,2]. Recently, transition-metal-mono substituted polyoxometalates were considered as a specific class of single-site catalysts where active metal is isolated in and strongly bound to an inorganic metal-oxide matrix [2–5]. Considerable efforts have been made to incorporate organic moieties within inorganic metal–silica frameworks (synthesis of the so-called hybrid organic–inorganic materials) to tune the surface properties and the catalytic performance [6,7]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are currently receiving significant attention for their potential applications in gas separation and storage, sensors, and catalysis [8–10]. Compared to conventionally used microporous and mesoporous inorganic materials, these metal-organic structures exhibit the potential for more flexible rational design, by controlling the size and the functionalization of the organic linkers [11]. MIL-101(Cr) is one of the porous MOF materials, which have been studied extensively [12–14]. MIL-101 is made from the linkage of 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate (BDC) anions and inorganic trimers that consist of three chromium atoms in an octahedral environment with four oxygen atoms of the bidentate dicarboxylate, one μ3O atom, and one oxygen atom from the terminal water or fluorine group [15]. Oxidation of sulfides is the most straightforward method for the synthesis of sulfoxides and sulfones, some examples of which are important as commodity chemicals and, in some cases, as pharmaceuticals [16]. This transformation has been performed in various ways [17–26]. However, the reported methods rarely offer the ideal combination of simplicity of method, rapid and selective reactions, and high yields of products and often suffer from a lack of generality and economical applicability. In this study, we report for the first time, the development of a new efficient V-containing Cr-MIL(101) system (denoted as V@MIL(101) hereafter) featuring a well-defined 3D, mesopore nano-rod structure exhibiting very high catalytic activity for the oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides and sulfones (Scheme 1 ). The effect of vanadium loading and impact of the MIL structure on the performance of the V-containing materials are discussed in the light of detailed characterization of the physicochemical properties of the catalysts by N2 adsorption, FTIR, XRD and TEM. 2 Experimental All materials were commercial reagent grade. Infrared spectra (400–4000cm−1) were recorded from KBr pellets on a Nicolet Impact 400 D spectrometer. Reaction courses and product mixtures were monitored by thin layer chromatography. The X-ray powdered diffraction patterns were performed on a Bruker-D8 advance with automatic control. The patterns were run with monochromatic Cu Kα (1.5406Å) radiation with a scan rate of 2°min−1. The BET specific surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts were determined by the adsorption/desorption of nitrogen at liquid nitrogen temperature with a Micromeritics Bel sorp mini II instrument. The pore sizes of the catalysts were obtained from the peak positions of the distribution curves determined from the adsorption branches of the isotherms. 2.1 Preparation of MIL-101(Cr) The synthesis of the MIL-101(Cr) catalysts was adapted from the literature [12]. For the synthesis of Cr-MIL(101) a mixture of 1.63g of chromium (III) nitrate, Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (97%), 0.7g of terephthalic acid, C6H4-1,4-(CO2H)2 (97%), 0.20g of hydrofluoric acid, HF (40%), and 20g of distilled water, H2O, was added in a Teflon container inside an autoclave. Then the autoclave was heated for 8h at 493K in an oven under static conditions. Once the synthesis was completed, the solid product was doubly filtered off using two glass filters with a pore size between 40 and 100μm to remove the free terephthalic acid. Then a solvothermal treatment was sequentially performed using ethanol (95% EtOH with 5% H2O) at 353K for 24h. The resulting solid was soaked in 1M of ammonium fluoride, NH4F, solution at 343K for 24h and was immediately filtered and washed with hot water. The solid was finally dried overnight and stored at 433K under air atmosphere. 2.2 Preparation of V@MIL(101) V@MIL(101) catalysts were prepared by an alcoholic impregnation method. A methanol solution of NH4VO3 to achieve a final V content of 1.4–5.6wt% of V atoms was contacted with the MIL carrier at 60°C, and the methanol was rotaevaporated until complete dryness. Then the catalysts were dried overnight in air at 120°C, followed by calcination at 600°C for 4h in air. 2.3 Synthesis of sulfoxides and sulfones To a stirred suspension of the selected sulphide (10mmol) and the heterogeneous catalyst 4.2% V@MIL(101) (0.1g, ~2.5mol%) in methanol (10ml), H2O2 (8mmol) was added in one portion. The slurry was stirred at room temperature for 20min. The catalyst was filtered off and washed with methanol (10ml). Ethyl acetate (10ml) was added and resulting solution was dried with anhydrous sodium sulphate and evaporated in vacuo to afford the crude product which was purified by column chromatography on silica gel (10% EtOAc in hexane) to afford the pure sulfoxide. Similar method was utilized to produce sulfones. In this case 4mol% of V@MIL(101) in CH3CN were utilized. 2.4 Selected spectroscopic data Dibutyl sulfoxide (2a): Mp 34–35°C. 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, δ): 0.97 (t, 6H, J =7.4Hz), 1.41–1.57 (m, 4H), 1.72–1.79 (m, 4H), 2.60–2.73 (m, 4H). 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3, δ): 13.64, 22.05, 24.56, 52.13. This notion is strengthened by CH weak peak at 3070cm−1. Strong bands in the region of 1800–1300cm−1 correspond to ν as(COO), ν s(COO), and ν(CC) vibrations, implying the presence of dicarboxylate linker in the MIL framework. Rather weak and narrow bands at 1017 and 749cm−1 can be attributed to δ(CH) and γ (CH) vibrations of aromatic rings, respectively. Weak bands in the spectral region of 700–400cm−1 are most likely due to in-plane and out-of-plane bending modes of COO-groups [27]. The peak with medium strength in 577cm−1 is due to CrO vibrations which prove that the metal organic framework indeed has been formed. The peak in 1560–1650cm−1 area relates to the vibration of CO group. The broad peak in 2400–3400cm−1 range can be because of crystalline water or the acidic OH of carbonyl group. The absence of a typical band at ca. 969–973cm−1ofV2O5 in Fig. 1b, implies that no crystalline V2O5 is formed in V@MIL-101 samples with V content <2.8wt%. This suggests that the vanadium species in V@MIL-101 samples are isolated, or at least highly dispersed, on the surface of the MCF materials [28–31]. The XRD patterns of all different Cr-MIL-101 samples are plotted in Fig. 2 . All samples showed good crystallinity. Fig. 2a presents the XRD patterns for the bare Cr-MIL(101). The main diffraction peaks were at 2θ =3.25, 5.10, 8.41, 9.02, 16.49, 17.40, and relative diffraction intensities of the prepared samples were found to be the same as the standard data for MIL-101 [12]. As observed previously for V-SBA [29] and V-MCF [31] systems, on low-angle X-ray diffraction, a slight shift of the primary peak to higher 2θ values, with a corresponding decrease in the peak intensity with increasing vanadium loading for the V-MIL samples up to 4.8% V-loading, were also noted. The shift of the primary peak to higher scattering angles can be taken as an indication of a slight decrease in the sphere diameters, possibly due to a contraction of their frameworks with increasing vanadium loading during the calcinations procedure. For 4.8% V-loading (Fig. 2d) the peak intensity for primary peak (2θ ~9) is highest but it is decrease for 5.6% V-loading again. The reduction of the scatterings after 4.8% V-loading may be caused by a partial structural collapse of the MIL pores such as V-MCF systems [31]. However, the arrangement of the MIL-101 frameworks was still well retained after incorporation of vanadia, as can be seen from the TEM and N2 adsorption data. The TEM images of V@Cr-MIL-101 sample is shown in Fig. 3 . Cr-MIL-101 is extremely sensitive to the electron beam, and in usual conditions, the structure collapses under the electron beam exposure [32]. The cubic symmetry of the MIL-101 was reflected in the shape of the crystals [33]. The cubic symmetry of the MIL-101 was not obtained for V@Cr-MIL-101 sample. The rod like surface morphology obtained for V@Cr-MIL-101.TEM analyses indicate that the continuous 3D pore structure of the Cr-MIL-101 is robust enough to survive the vanadium incorporation process and so offers an excellent matrix to support highly dispersed vanadium species. The places with darker contrast could be assigned to the presence of vanadium oxide particles with different dispersion. The small dark spots in the images could be ascribed to vanadium oxide particles, probably located in to the Cr-MIL-101 cavities. The larger dark areas over the cavities most likely correspond to vanadium oxide agglomerates on the external surface. Structural properties of MIL-101 are listed in Table 1 . MIL-101 showed BET surface area of 2191m2/g and pore volume of 0.61cm3/g. After vanadium oxide modification, the nitrogen adsorption isotherm became an even line and the volume adsorbed decreased distinctly, suggesting the occupation of the pore by vanadium oxide. BET surface area and pore volume of V@Cr-MIL-101 samples decreased which confirms that vanadium oxide have occupied the channels in MIL-101. DRUV–vis spectra of MIL-101 and V@MIL-101 samples is shown in Fig. 4 . The spectra of the MIL-101 samples exhibited at least two absorption bands (i) at 434 and (ii) at 611nm. They are ascribed to the A 2g → T 1g and A 2g → T 2g d–d transitions due to Cr(III) [34]. Upon addition of NH4VO3 and calcination step (V@MIL-101) the bands due to Cr3+ observed before strongly decreased. DRUV–vis spectra of 4.2 V@MIL-101 samples (Fig. 4b) show two intense absorption bands at 258 and 322nm. These bands are attributed to charge transfer transitions associated with O2− to V5+ [35]. The charge transfer bands at 258nm are consistent with V5+ in tetrahedral environment, the other charge transfer band at 322nm is attributed to V5+ with VO double bond and VO single bonds [36,37]. Indeed, these bands closely resemble those of NH4VO3 [38] indicating isolated tetrahedral environment of V5+ in the MIL-101 matrix, which is in good agreement with literature [37]. On the other hand, the bands at 258 and 322nm may also be assigned to distorted tetrahedral arrangement of V5+ (as a result of immobilizing/anchoring on the pore windows of MIL-101) in a way similar to that reported for various vanadium-loaded/grafted amorphous/mesoporous silica materials [37,39]. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Oxidation to sulfides The oxidation of PhSMe using H2O2 which did not proceed in the absence of catalyst under mild conditions was used as a model reaction. To find optimum reaction conditions, the influence of different factors affecting the conversion and selectivity of the oxidation reaction such as catalyst concentration, solvent nature and the molar ratio of H2O2/sulfide, were investigated in this study. Performing the oxidation reaction of PhSMe in the presence of 2mol% of 4.2% V@Cr-MIL-101 catalyst and 8mol% of H2O2 in ethanol improved markedly the conversion of substrate (63%) (Table 2 , entry 3). It was observed that the highest yield and selectivity to sulfoxide were achieved in the presence of 3mol% of the catalyst within 60min. Also an increase in the catalyst/sulfide molar ratio up to 10mol% does not affect the reaction rate and yield of sulfoxide product in this catalytic system (Table 2, entry 8).The influence of solvent nature on the selectivity and reaction rate in this reaction system was also studied. From the examination of seven reaction solvents such as dichloromethane, acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, water and ethanol in this catalytic reaction, it was observed that three protic solvents, methanol, water and especially ethanol, significantly enhanced the yield and the selectivity of sulfoxide product (Fig. 5 ). The eco-friendly property of ethanol (98%) strongly induced us to employ it as the reaction solvent in this oxidation system. In this green solvent we obtained 98% yield of sulfoxide without any over oxidation to sulfone. It should be mention that the use of dried ethanol as the reaction media decreases the selectivity of sulfoxide (92%) and no affect on the conversion rate was observed. Encouraged by the excellent catalytic performance for the PhSMe oxidation to sulfoxide, different sulfides were subjected to the reaction system in the presence of H2O2/V@MIL(101), and the results are listed in Table 3 . All substrates could be smoothly converted to sulfoxides with good to high conversion rates, and excellent selectivities were obtained under mild conditions. The highest yields were obtained for dialkyl and diallylsulfide (95–98%) after 0.5h. The replacement of one or both alkyl or aryl groups with phenyl or benzyl group enhanced the reaction times (3 versus 0.5h); however, no regular trends in electronic and steric requirements have been observed. It should be mentioned that the present catalytic system was highly selective. Sulfoxides could be nearly stoichiometrically produced and the generation of the corresponding sulfones was well controlled, which makes this process a good alternative for sulfoxide production. However, the changing of solvent from EtOH to CH3CN (with the same ratio of H2O2/sulfide) conduct a new procedure for easy access to sulfone products with high/excellent yields under the influence of the higher concentration of catalyst (4mol% instead of 3mol%) (Table 3). Another salient feature of the present sulfoxidation system is its excellent chemo-selectivity. A sulfide also having a carbon–carbon double bond (Table 3, entries i and k), was cleanly transformed into the corresponding sulfoxide in excellent yield. In addition, benzyl phenyl and 4-Br-benzyl benzyl sulfides (Table 3, entries h and d) were selectively oxidized to their corresponding sulfoxide without formation of any benzylic oxidation by-products. The good to high yields of oxidation products (78–98%) obtained by this catalytic system in desired times (0.5–3h) indicate the high efficiency of V@MIL(101), catalyst. More evidences for this important feature of the present catalyst have been obtained by determining of the turnover frequency (TON/h=TOF) and total turnover numbers of V@MIL(101), indicating the activity and stability of catalyst during the oxidation reaction, respectively (TON=mol product/mol catalyst). It is evident that the V@MIL(101)/H2O2 system allows these transformations to proceed with excellent selectivity, high yield and milder conditions. Furthermore, the use of V@MIL(101) makes this method simple, inexpensive, more convenient and practical. Additionally, competitive V@MIL(101) catalyzed oxidation reaction of equimolar amounts of methylphenyl sulfide and benzaldehyde at room temperature lead to the selective formation methylphenyl sulfoxide in good yield, whereas benzaldehyde remaind unchanged (Scheme 2 ). In order to show the merit of the present work in comparison with recently reported protocols [18–26], we compared the results with respect to the amounts of the catalysts used, reaction times and yields of the products (Table 4 ). Comparison of 4.2 V@MIL(101) with these catalysts for selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides show that activity of 4.2 V@MIL(101) seems to be higher than or equal with other known catalysts (Table 4). The recovery and reusability of the catalyst has been investigated. We have noticed that after the addition of CHCl3 to the reaction mixture, this catalyst can be easily recovered quantitatively by simple filtration. The wet catalyst was recycled (the nature of the recovered catalysts has been followed by NAA, XRD and FT-IR spectra) and no appreciable change in activity was noticed after eight cycles (Fig. 6 ). 3.2.2 Oxidation to sulfones In order to demonstrate the efficiency and applicability of the H2O2/V@MIL(101) system further, the chemoselective oxidation of sulphide to sulfones was also investigated. The reaction conditions specified in Table 3 was optimized for carrying out the reaction in CH3CN at room temperature (sulphide/H2O/V@MIL(101) ratio: 1:8:4). It was found that a wide variety of diaryl, dialkyl, dibenzyl, aryl benzyl, alkyl aryl and cyclic sulphides were oxidized to their corresponding sulfones in excellent yields in CH3CN at room temperature. The results are summarized in Table 3. 3.2.3 Catalytic oxidative desulfurization of commodity gasoline To investigate whether the catalytic oxidative desulfurization system is effective to commodity gasoline, the catalytic oxidation desulfurization was carried out with PW12@MCFim (as a model catalyst) on a commercial gasoline sample obtained from the national Iranian oil refining and distribution company (NIORDC). The sulfur-containing compounds in the gasoline could be oxidized with a mixture containing V@MIL(101) (0.1g) and H2O2 (8mol%) at 25°C for 10h. The upper phase was withdrawn and analyzed by an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer. The total sulfur level of gasoline was decreased from 1423μg/g to 232μg/g, which suggested that the V@MIL(101) catalyst had high catalytic activity for all kinds of sulfur-containing compounds present in the commodity gasoline sample. 4 Conclusions For the first time, a series of mesoporous V-containing metal organic framework nano-rod catalysts (V@MIL(101)) were prepared by the wet impregnation method. The arrangement of the Cr-MIL(101) framework is retained upon vanadium incorporation at least up to a V loading of 4.2% and, therefore, high surface areas were obtained for the 4.2% V@MIL(101). The V@MIL(101) is an excellent heterogeneous system for promoting the highly chemoselective and rapid oxidation of functionalized sulfides with H2O2 under mild conditions. It is noteworthy that the reaction tolerates oxidatively sensitive functional groups and the sulfur atom is selectively oxidized. The total sulfur level of commodity gasoline was decreased from 1423μg/g to 232μg/g in the V@MIL(101) catalytic oxidation system, which could provide a new possible means for the catalytic oxidative desulfurization of gasoline using H2O2 as the oxidant. coredata.dc:description: Porous materials based on chromium (III) terephthalate metal organic frameworks (Cr-MIL(101)) and their new composites with vanadium oxide has emerged as a potential catalyst because of its high specific surface area, tunable pore size, and unique structure. The structural and textural characterization of V@MIL(101) were done using FTIR, X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption–desorption, and TEM. XRD and adsorption–desorption analysis shows that the mesostructure of MIL-101 remains intact after vanadium oxide modifications, while spectral technique show the successful immobilizing of the neat vanadium oxide inside the MIL-101 cavities. These new catalysts were found to be highly effective for selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides and sulfones with H2O2 at room temperature and the 4.2% V@MIL(101) catalyst showed the highest activity. The PW12@MCFim heterogeneous system showed high catalytic oxidative activity in the treatment of commodity gasoline.
coredata.dc:title: Nano-rod catalysts: Building MOF bottles (MIL-101 family as heterogeneous single-site catalysts) around vanadium oxide ships
